segments.pli: Aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes?”

segments.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
segments.en: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does both kinds of deeds by body, speech, and mind.
‘The egg-born phoenixes are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

segments.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
segments.en: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes!’

segments.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
segments.en: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
segments.en: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes.”

suttaplex.blurb: One becomes an egg born phoenix due to ambivalent deeds in a past life and the appropriate aspiration.
